- black pepper

1.	Heat the oil in a large, non-stick saucepan over a medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and fry for 2-3 minutes, stirring occasionally, until softened and just beginning to colour.
2.	Add the risotto rice to the pan and stir well for 30-40 seconds, until the oil has coated the grains of rice.
3.	Pour in half of the wine and allow to bubble for 30-40 seconds, then add all of the stock and bring to the boil, stirring well. Reduce the heat and simmer, uncovered, for 8-10 minutes, stirring frequently, until the rice is almost tender and the risotto is creamy in appearance.
4.	Stir in the remaining wine, the chicken and the frozen peas, then continue to cook, stirring constantly, for a further 4-5 minutes, or until the chicken and peas are heated through and the rice is tender with a slight bite.
5.	Remove the pan from the heat, then stir in the butter and cheese. Season with black pepper. Cover the pan with a lid and set aside for 5 minutes before serving

- large eggs
- unsalted butter
- whole milk or heavy cream
- chopped chives
- country bread, toasted

1.	In a small bowl, lightly beat the eggs
2.	Heat butter in a small saucepan over medium heat until foamy
3.	Add eggs and cook, whisking, until they begin to set
4.	gently whisk in milk and chives
5.	Remove from heat and serve with toasted bread

- skin-on, pork belly
- Shaoxing wine
- pale green parts of scallions
- sliced ginger
- light soy sauce
- garlic cloves

1.	Bring a large pot of water to a boil
2.	Add pork and cook, skimming off foam from surface, 5 minutes
3.	Transfer pork to paper towels to drain
4.	Wipe out pot
5.	Heat 3 Tbsp
6.	Water in pot over medium-high
7.	Add sugar, stir to dissolve, and cook, stirring constantly, until syrup thickens and turns a pale amber color, about 4 minutes
8.	Reduce heat to medium and return pork to pot, swirling so all sides are covered in caramel
9.	Add pale green parts of scallions, ginger, garlic, and star anise
10.	Cook, tossing, until fragrant, about 1 minute
11.	Add soy sauce and wine and cook, stirring, until slightly reduced, about 1 minute
12.	Pour in water (just barely cover pork)
13.	Bring to a boil
14.	Reduce heat to low (cook 50–60 minutes)
15.	transfer pork to a plate, remove pot from heat
16.	Let sauce cooking liquid cool slightly so rendered fat can rise to the surface
17.	Skim off as much fat as possible (save it for another use)
18.	Return pot to medium heat and cook, stirring occasionally, until sauce is slightly thickened and glossy, 12–15 minutes
19.	Return pork to pot and toss to gently reheat and coat with sauce
20.	Transfer pork to a platter. Pour sauce over.
